p: Many major public health organizations and leaders recognize climate change as an urgent public health issue [ 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18] and have argued that there is an immediate need to develop a national public health workforce that can research and address the effects of climate change on human health [ 19, 20, 21]. Some state and local public health departments are conducting projects on climate adaptation, through funding from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention [ 22, 23, 24, 25, 26], and many public health departments and programs are doing work that can achieve greenhouse (GHG) reductions, which is an important aspect of preventing further climate change (e.g., promoting physical activity through walking and biking) [ 27].
